title: Projects
text: Currently, I am developing a bioinformatics pipeline to assess the editing efficiency and off-target effects of cir-arRNAs using long-read sequencing. This framework will preserve transcript-specific information and enable accurate evaluation of RNA editing outcomes. This research merges my computational skills with molecular biology, supporting the lab’s efforts in RNA biology and advancing my understanding of gene regulatory processes.

title: Projects
section: scRNAseq Cell-Type Indentifier Benchmarking for HSPCs
text:
scRNAseq Cell-Type Indentifier Benchmarking for HSPCs
Through the UCLA Bruins-in-Genomics Summer Research Program, I compared single-cell RNA sequencing classifiers for hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs). I evaluated cell-type correspondence across whole and HSPC-purified datasets. Our results demonstrated the need for resolution-matched identifiers, a critical insight for scRNA-seq studies.

title: Projects
text:
Pipeline for Viral Population Prediction
I was a student researcher through the RUSH University Summer Research Program. Here, I learnt topics in bioinformatics. First, I designed a pipeline to predict bacteriophage populations from metagenomics data to use in a machine learning model. Then, I investigated lncRNA expression across mice under eight lifestyle conditions.

title: Projects
text:
Inheritance of Phage Immune Genes
During my freshman year, I participated in the HHMI SEA-PHAGES program, which introduced me to bioinformatics. I characterized and annotated the genomes of two novel actinobacteriophages. I also designed an independent research project that investigated the conserved inheritance of immune genes in phages. We hypothesized that certain integrase-repressor combinations were deleterious to phage evolution, causing their strict paired inheritance. Furthermore, if these pairs were well defined between different families of phages, they could offer a better method to classify phages.

title: Aryahi Deorukhkar
text:
Welcome to my website!
Hello, I am Aryahi, an undergraduate student at Case Western Reserve University. I come from a quite culturally diverse background, having lived in India, Germany, and now the United States. I am currently a senior majoring in Biochemistry with specializations in cancer biology, quantitative health science, and metabolism. I hope to go to grad school next year and pursue a PhD in genomics and bioinformatics.
In grad school, I aim to further analyze large genetic datasets and find insightful conclusions about health and disease. To do this, I want to create new bioinformatics techniques that can be used for sequencing data. RNA biology is another exciting field that I am interested in. We can take advantage of the dual function of RNA as an information-carrying molecule with enzymatic properties to regulate gene expression.
I hope that this website is informative for you to get to know more about me and my scholarly interests! Please contact me on my email for further inquiries or questions.
